children.subject: Will Professor Rao post a follow-up with the CS170 perspective?

history.content:
"Hi folks, 

I hope you're keeping your heads above water as we enter the final stretch of the semester.  And if you know how, do let me know, too, please;  I can use some pointers on staying afloat. :P

I've received enough e-mails about the subject that I think it's a good idea for me to spam the list. 

Unfortunately, the lecture times for CS 170 and EE 120 conflict next fall.  I'm truly sorry about this.  As much as our scheduling staff and we try, we don't always succeed.  There are so many moving targets when it comes to scheduling classrooms on this campus, that fixing one leak tends to create new ones.

Given that we must deal with the reality of this conflict, here are my thoughts: 

1. I'm not a fan of taking two courses whose lectures conflict.  Generally, it's a bad idea (unless you *already have* a history of walking on water). You're likely to give neither course its fair due, and each of the two courses will reciprocate by not bringing you due benefit. Please pick one and proceed. 

2. If you choose to take both courses against your better judgment and my advice, then know that I do not have a final exam in EE 120.  Accordingly, a final exam conflict should not be on your worry list. 

However, I do have in-class, lecture-time midterms and quizzes (likely three of each, and the quizzes might be pop). You do not want to miss lecture on those days.  I will not burden my TAs---who, like you, are students---with extra hours of proctoring, just because some students knowingly take two courses that conflict in schedule. 

3. I don't use a textbook for EE 120.  It's not clear that I'll have funding from the Department to have the course on full Webcast. That makes it even more critical for students taking the course to be physically present in the classroom---not lost in Banach space---during lecture. 

I won't stop anyone from cross-registering between CS 170 and EE 120 this fall. But, as I said, I won't burden my staff with extra work on account of students who choose to dive into a lecture-conflict situation.

All the best to you in the final descent into the finals exams, on these final days of this fine semester. 

Cheers,
Babak."
history.subject: EE 120 and CS 170 Schedule Conflict in the Fall
